entry.title: Combined summary - BIP proposal: Generalized version bits voting (bip-genvbvoting)
entry.summary: In the world of Bitcoin, BIP 9 is a mechanism that helps coordinate softforks among miners to make the upgrade process smoother. However, it does not apply to hardforks as miners are not relevant to them. While there is no fundamental distinction between the role of miners in softforks and hardforks when it comes to proper coordination with the rest of the users in the system, BIP 9 can be used as a coordination mechanism for both softforks and hardforks.Sancho Panza has proposed a new informational BIP called bip-genvbvoting to replace BIP9. The author argues that BIP9 limits itself to backward-compatible changes and has a fixed 95% threshold that is not flexible enough to represent varying degrees of contentiousness. The author suggests creating three default sets of properties for the 30 bits available and pushing the signaling configuration into an external configuration file that adheres to a fixed format and could easily be adapted and shared between implementations.Luke Dashjr discussed how BIP 9 provides a mechanism for miners to coordinate softforks, but not hardforks. He explained that miners are essentially irrelevant to hardforks and cannot make the process any smoother. Tom Zander asked for an explanation of how miners are irrelevant to non-soft fork upgrades. Miners are irrelevant when it comes to hardforks as they cannot make the process any smoother.The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) 9 provides a mechanism for miners to coordinate soft forks, but it is not useful for deploying hard forks. BIP 9 limits itself to backward-compatible changes, making it unsuitable for hard forks. The fixed 95% threshold in BIP 9 is not flexible enough to account for a "spectrum of contentiousness" and can allow small minorities to veto proposed changes, leading to stagnation. However, it should be noted that soft forks are not required to use BIP 9, and even if they do, they are not obligated to adhere to the recommended thresholds.Most bits are unused today, and someone wishing to use a bit for a feature deployment would announce so publicly in a BIP and release an implementation that is suitably configured. Others wishing to provide compatibility with that feature would adjust their code and bip-genvbvoting configuration files accordingly. Sancho Panza has submitted a rough draft proposal for a new informational BIP called 'bip-genvbvoting' that aims to create a more flexible consensus-finding scheme that can adapt to the needs of the market and ensure the Bitcoin protocol remains competitive as an electronic payment system. The proposed scheme allows each version bit to be treated individually using a configurable percentage threshold and window size. The author suggests eliminating references to fixed values and replacing them with respective parameters. A reference implementation can be constructed after elaboration of the specification. The BIP's reference implementation should provide strict BIP9 compatibility, and someone wishing to use a bit for a feature deployment would announce it publicly in a BIP. The author suggests creating three default sets of properties for different bit ranges but does not see the point of the BIP doing so.On April 3, 2017, a Bitcoin developer named Sancho Panza raised concerns about the shortcomings of BIP 9 in an email to the bitcoin-dev mailing list. In summary, while Panza identified certain issues with BIP 9, some argue that these problems are not unique to BIP 9 and that the limitations of soft forks are simply inherent to the technology. Additionally, soft forks are not bound to use the recommended thresholds in BIP 9.
